title: Kano review: Grime legend took us to church at London’s Royal Albert Hall
text:
Kano was simply iconic (Picture: WireImage)

If Kano simply did the opening track and left the stage at London’s Royal Albert Hall, it would have been enough to send us off into the night feeling happy and our hearts full.

It’s impossible for the grime stalwart’s ferocious energy not to consume your soul, even with the fewest bars.

Perhaps he’s been raring to get back on tour after a few years’ break, maybe he’s spurred on by the critical-acclaim of his performance in Top Boy, or perhaps it’s the momentous occasion of performing at the prestigious Royal Albert Hall?

Or probably all three.

Needless to say, it’s rare for a grime artist to tread the boards of the historic west London venue. But there was certainly no indication that Kano felt out of place – he undoubtedly belonged there.

Kano somewhat eased us into the show with the first half pretty much dominated by the vocal support of his gospel choir.

Dressed in all white, you’d be mistaken for thinking he’d just come from Kanye’s Sunday Service but his talented choir are certainly a match for ‘Ye’s fleet of gospel singers.

Oh, hey Giggs (Picture: WireImage)

No, this isn’t Kanye’s Sunday Service (Picture: WireImage)

The choir particularly shone on tracks from Hoodies All Summer, Kano’s latest album which was revered by fans and critics alike.

Whether they’re acoustically singing ‘suck your mum’ so eloquently on SYM or offering support on the emotionally-charged and electric Teardrops, the choir well and truly made sure Kano took us to church.

And it was truly a blessing.

Hoodies All Summer offers the perfect mash-up of lyrically-conscious numbers to arresting grime bangers and, when pieced together with Kano’s extensive back catalogue, made for a brilliantly eclectic show weaving from one sound to the next.

True delights came from the roaring grime section, which featured surprise appearances from D Double E and Ghetts to assist on Class of Deja, a sort of tribute to the grime of yesteryear.

What a night (Picture: WireImage)

Giggs sharing the stage with Kano on 3 Wheels Up made for a particularly glorious moment, even if Wiley was missing from the formation.

Kano’s breakout hit Ps and Qs earned a similar rapturous reaction and it was probably the first time the Royal Albert Hall floors had shook.

It certainly kept us on our toes so it’s no surprise that it happened to the most engaging audience we’ve come across in a long while.

Advertisement

Typically, concert-goers are dashing off to catch their last tube home but Kano’s die-hard followers were lapping up every last drop until the bitter end, a sign of a job well done and then some.

Hoodies All Summer is considered a masterpiece, much like this iconic performance.

And so we did go off into the night, happy and with our souls full.

Kano’s latest album, Hoodies All Summer, is available to buy and stream now. His tour will resume in January.
